title: China criticises  Australian and Canadian warships transiting Taiwan Strait
text:
The US Navy and, on occasion, ships from allied countries including Canada, Britain and France transit the strait, which they consider an international waterway, around once a month.

Taiwan

also considers it an international waterway.

title: 'Miracle no one was hit': Car smashes through alterations shop
text:
A car has gone crashing into an alterations shop in Adelaide, with witnesses hailing it a "miracle" that no one was injured.

Emergency crews were called to George Street in Norwood about 11.30am today.

CCTV captured the silver Toyota making a U-turn and swiping three cars before driving onto a footpath on the opposite side of the road.

A car has come crashing into an alterations shop in Adelaide, with witnesses hailing it a "miracle" that no one was injured. (Supplied)

The car was seen knocking over a street sign and narrowly avoiding two women before it crashed into the alterations shop.

"Very loud, very loud," witness Sue Duong said.

Witnesses rushed to help the driver, a 46-year-old man from Kent Town, and called for help.

Firefighters worked to free the man, and the car was later towed away. ﻿

The driver was treated at the scene for minor injuries and fined for the crash.

The shop owner told 9News he was inside at the time, but was luckily in the back corner of the store﻿.

"It's ﻿a miracle no one was hit," Duong said.

title: Sharyce looks perfectly healthy but hasn't been able to work in years
text:
Sharyce Helyar looks perfectly healthy but she hasn't been able to work in years.

﻿The 27-year-old from Adelaide lives with arthritis, which is the second most common cause for time taken off work in Australia (after traumatic injury).

It's also the second most common cause of early retirement due to ill-health.﻿

Sharyce Helyar, 27, looks perfectly healthy but she hasn't been able to work in years. (Supplied)

By 2030, the ﻿loss of personal income due to arthritis is projected to hit $2.6 billion.

But many Australians still mistakenly believe someone Helyar's age couldn't have arthritis, despite the fact she's been living with it for more than 20 years.

Almost 65 per cent of Australians mistakenly believe arthritis mainly affects people over 65, according to new YouGov polling commissioned by Arthritis Australia.

But two-thirds of the 4.11 million cases in Australia are in working-age adults, young people and children.

In fact, Helyar was just four when she was diagnosed with ﻿juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

She was later diagnosed with ﻿psoriatic arthritis as well and has been been managing joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and fatigue ever since.

It held her back at school and though she tried to power through at university, it eventually forced her to abandon a ﻿degree in medical radiation science.

"I think there was a lot of pressure I put on myself because I wanted to be a normal young adult, and I wanted to have the uni experience," Helyar told 9news.com.au.

"I didn't want my arthritis, my disability to stop me from doing that."

Helyar was just four when she was diagnosed with juvenile idiopathic arthritis. (Supplied)

More than 70 per cent of Aussies underestimate the burden of arthritis and fail to recognise that it and other musculoskeletal conditions a leading cause of time taken off work.

For almost four years of study, Helyar underestimated it too.

She thought she was managing her pain and fatigue ﻿well at uni, only to land in the emergency department in her fourth year.

Her body could no longer keep up with the physical demands of her degree placements.

Ultimately, Helyar had to give up on her dream of a career in medical radiology.﻿

"My body just wasn't able to do what I physically wanted it to do," she said.

"I had to reassess everything in my life, which was really confronting and scary, and a lot of grief went with it, because I had my life mapped out out and now it all had to change."

READ MORE: Joe Biden undergoes surgery to remove skin cancer on forehead

The five qualifications in hot demand for Australia's future jobs View Gallery

The university worked with Helyar to help her graduate with a different degree but her arthritis has made it impossible for her to enter her chosen industry.

﻿She's also been unable to return to part-time or gig work she did while studying.

After 22 years with arthritis, permanent damage has been done to her joints and the pain and stiffness she experiences has become harder to manage.﻿

The fatigue has become so severe Helyar can usually only leave the house twice a week before her body gives out.

﻿"I'm unable to work until I find a solution," she said.

"And there might not be a solution for my pain, and my fatigue might not get better."

Arthritis is incurable, so Helyar's chances of entering the workforce are limited by her treatment options.

But funding for arthritis research is limited and ﻿not being able to earn a living in a cost of living crisis is a scary prospect.

Helyar is just one of the ﻿2.8 million working-age Australians living with arthritis who face uncertain futures.

By 2030, the ﻿loss of personal income due to arthritis is projected to hit $2.6 billion, costing the government more than $1.1 billion a year in extra welfare payments and lost taxation revenue.

Lost GDP from ﻿arthritis-related early retirement is expected to reach $9.4 billion a year by 2030 as well.

Even if Helyar was able to work, there's no guarantee that employers would be undersanding of her health needs.

In the past, Helyar chose not to disclose her condition to employers out of fear they would make assumptions about her ability to do a job.

READ MORE: Officer killed in Porepunkah shooting farewelled at Victoria Police Academy

Helyar was forced to abandon her career goals because of her invisible illness. (Supplied)

﻿"People make the assumptions and you can see that they're thinking something, even if they don't actually say it," she said.

"There's definitely a lot of misconceptions about arthritis being an 'older person' condition, people just aren't aware that it affects people of all ages and in a variety of ways."

Those misconceptions go beyond the workplace as well.﻿

Some people assume that because she's young, her arthritis ﻿must be less painful or more manageable.

Others judge her when they see her using mobility aids like a wheelchair when her symptoms make it hard to walk.﻿

But arthritis can be just as debilitating for a 20-something as it can be ﻿for someone in their 80s.

Since her health declined at uni, Helyar has had to move back home and currently relies on her family for support with ﻿everyday tasks like cleaning, shopping and laundry.

It's a far cry from the radiology ﻿career she had envisioned for herself, but she's found new purpose through advocacy.

Helyar now puts her energy into advocacy, especially championing other young people with arthritis. (Supplied)

This week﻿ she even attended a parliamentary event alongside Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to raise awareness of the impact arthritis has on Aussies of all ages in recognition of Arthritis Australia's 75th anniversary.

"We need more awareness that it does affect people of all ages, and it is a disability, it's not just a small condition that doesn't impact life in a big way," Helyar said.

"The more people talk about it and are open about their experiences with it, the more people will learn."

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: Tesla proposes Elon Musk pay package that could make him the world's first trillionaire
text:
Elon Musk, already the world's richest person, could become the first trillionaire after the Tesla board unveiled a massive new pay package for its CEO to keep his focus on the troubled EV maker.

The package would grant him additional shares of Tesla stock if the company is able to grow far beyond its current value, with a market capitalisation far greater than any company has ever approached. Musk's previous pay package, which added significantly to his massive wealth, also laid out ambitious growth plans that once appeared to be a reach – but which Tesla proved able to reach easily.

The new pay package could grant Musk 423.7 million additional shares of Tesla stock. Those shares would be worth $US143.5 billion ($218.6 billion) at today's stock value.

Elon Musk could become the world's first trillionaire if shareholders adopt a new proposal that would give him unprecedented sums of money if the company reaches certain ambitious milestones. (Andrew Harnik/Getty Images via CNN Newsource)

But Musk would get those shares only if the value of Tesla stock increases significantly in coming years. The company stock would need to reach an overall value of $US8.5 trillion ($12.95 trillion) for Musk to get all the shares, significantly above the current market capitalisation of $US1.1 trillion ($1.68 trillion).

Those 423.7 million new shares that Musk would get under this package would be worth close to $US1 trillion ($1.52 trillion) should the company hit the increased valuation targets spelled out in Friday's proxy statement.

If Tesla shares are able to reach the $US8.5 billion market capitalisation value, it could become the most valuable company ever. It would be worth roughly double the current market value of Nvidia (NVDA), the current most-valuable company on the market. Tesla is already the most valuable automaker by a large margin, even though legacy automakers, like second-most valuable automaker Toyota, sell far more vehicles and now make more profits.

Proposal for Tesla in invest in xAI

The company's proxy statement that laid out Musk's payment plan also included a shareholder proposal that Tesla take a stake in privately-held xAI, the artificial intelligence company that Musk also owns. That could help Elon Musk further consolidate his growing business empire.

XAI recently purchased X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter, which Musk bought for $US44 billion of his own money in 2022. The company did not take a position for or against that shareholder proposal, which does not give any details of how large a stake Tesla should take in xAI, and what price.

But any such investment could further enrich Tesla since Musk is the primary owner of xAI.

READ MORE: Fears accused killer Dezi Freeman could be down a mine shaft

If Tesla shares are able to reach the $US8.5 billion market capitalisation value, it could become the most valuable company ever. (AP)

Musk currently owns 410 million shares of Tesla shares, worth $US139 billion at Thursday's closing price. That stake, along with his stakes in xAI, rocket company SpaceX, and several other companies he has started and runs, have made him the richest person on the planet, worth $US378 billion according to Bloomberg's billionaire tracker.

He currently has options to buy an additional 304 million shares of Tesla, but a judge in Delaware has twice struck down that 2018 pay package that granted him those options as illegal. Those rulings came despite overwhelming approval by Tesla shareholders – twice. The company again has tried to grant those options to Musk this year, and adding in those options, he now owns 18 per cent of the company's shares.

Tesla shares nearly doubled in value to a record-high price for its shares between election day and mid-December 2024, as investors bet that his close ties to US President Donald Trump would be a boon for Tesla. But as Tesla faced protests and dropping sales and falling profits in backlash to those ties (before he had a falling out with Trump), all those things resulted in Telsa's stock losing those gains. The shares have recovered some of those losses, but they are still down 26 per cent from the December peak.

Still, Musk and his fans on Wall Street have insisted the company is well positioned to grow even larger and more successful in the future. He has continued to predict that his plans for self-driving cars – including a robotaxi service – will create massive profits and value for shareholders. The robotaxis would provide rides to passengers and also allow Tesla owners to rent out their cars for driverless rides when not in use.

Tesla shares nearly doubled in value to a record-high price for its shares between election day and mid-December 2024, as investors bet that his close ties to US President Donald Trump would be a boon for Tesla. (AP)

Musk has also promised a line of humanoid robots that could bring in even more sales than Tesla's car business.

Keeping Musk focused on Tesla

"It's a big pay package but Tesla needs to keep its biggest asset in Musk as CEO," Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives told CNN on Friday. Ives is one of the bigger Tesla bulls on Wall Street.

"In this AI era Musk now will drive its next leg of growth," Ives added. "The Board had a $1 trillion decision and made the right one."

The board's proxy statement spoke of the importance of keeping Musk focused on Tesla going forward. In addition to his many business interests, he remains active in politics, despite his falling out with Trump. He has announced plans to form a third political party.

Tesla, in its proxy statement, warned that it needed to incentivise Musk to focus his attention on growing the company. It said that during the negotiations on the pay package, "Musk also raised the possibility that he may pursue other interests that may afford him greater influence if he did not receive such assurances."

The board said it "believes that Mr Musk singularly possesses the leadership characteristics necessary to transform Tesla and realise its long-term mission at an unparalleled level".

Musk currently owns 410 million shares of Tesla shares, worth $US139 billion at Thursday's closing price. (AP)

But the company said it is also making plans for life after Musk, saying it is already working on succession plans. And it said that one of the terms of the employment package that Musk must meet to receive the final 70 million shares of stock is that he needs to have "developed a framework for Chief Executive Officer succession".

"The board regularly discusses management succession planning and leadership development," said the proxy statement. It said those succession plans are "for both sudden, unanticipated events, in addition to longer-term planned succession for its executives". It said it "believes that management has developed a robust pipeline of seasoned leadership talent within Tesla," and that is also looking at possible external talent.

Musk does not receive a cash salary from Tesla. All of his compensation comes from Tesla shares and options he has been granted in the past. Since there is still an ongoing court fight over the 304 million options, Musk has not received any compensation for nearly a decade, since a 2012 pay package made its last disbursement of options to him in 2017.

But not all tech billionaires receive additional stock options or grants as compensation, instead benefiting from the increased valuations of their existing stakes in their companies. That includes Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and Mark Zuckerberg, who co-founded Facebook. Both took large stakes in their companies as founders, but neither has received stock grants or options since those companies had initial public offerings in 1997 and 2012, respectively.

Tesla faced protests and dropping sales and falling profits in backlash to Musk's ties to Donald Trump. (Getty)

If Musk and his fans are right, Musk would become far wealthier even without any additional shares of Tesla stock. His current holdings of 410 million Tesla shares, even without the disputed 304 million options, would be worth nearly $US1 trillion more than today's valuation, should Tesla's market cap rise to $US8.5 billion.

Despite promises, Tesla faces problems

But to achieve that target, it would have to start doing the things Musk is promising in terms of self-driving vehicles and its robotaxi. And that would mean meeting grand claims from a man and company that have often fallen short of their promises.

Tesla critics say that the stock has become grossly overvalued because of Wall Street's willingness to buy into Musk's vision of the future in terms of AI, self-driving vehicles and robots, despite its failures to deliver on past promises along those lines.

"Elon Musk has been saying since 2014 'we will have a fully autonomous car next year'. It hasn't happened, but that promise has been valued in the billions by Wall Street," said analyst Gordon Johnson, one of the harsher critics of Tesla. "Elon Musk is a master manipulator. He's been able to keep the stock elevated. The reason the board is paying him is he's willing to say things that other CEOs aren't willing to say or get away with."

The richest man's relationship with the president eventually soured before he abandoned the administration. (AP)

Tesla is facing growing competition from Chinese EV makers. BYD, one of those Chinese automakers, is poised to pass Tesla for the most EV sales worldwide, even though it is not available for sale in the United States.

Tesla also faces competition from other companies that are ahead of it in providing robotaxi services, including Waymo, the autonomous vehicle unit of Google parent Alphabet, which has its own service and has partnered with Uber in some cities.

And a change in US law is about to remove a $7500 tax credit for buyers of most electric vehicles, which could cause prices and sales of those vehicles to fall sharply.

US law also recently removed the billions of dollars in penalties that traditional automakers have had to pay if their gas-powered vehicles exceed emissions rules. The way that they avoided those payments in the past was by buying regulatory credits from an EV maker like Tesla. But the payments that brought billions in revenue to Tesla will now vanish.

Johnson said that Tesla's stock price is therefore unlikely to hit the ambitious targets laid out in this Musk pay package.

Musk has also promised a line of humanoid robots that could bring in even more sales than Tesla's car business. (AP)

"Things are going to get worse for them, not better," said Johnson. "Is Tesla going to go to $8 trillion? Abso-f---ing-lutely not."

Shares of Tesla (TSLA) were up about 5 per cent in early trading on the news.

title: Think house prices are bad now? They're about to get much worse
text:
Australians wanting to buy their first home are about to find that already-tricky task even more difficult, with house prices set to rise by as much as $154,000 by the end of next year.

Westpac has forecast that dwelling prices will increase by 6 per cent this calendar year before a further 8 per cent hike in 2026, thanks in part to the Reserve Bank's three recent interest rate cuts.

According to Canstar, those increases would see Sydney's median house price rise by a little more than $154,000 between now and the end of next year, taking it up to about $1.67 million.

House prices are set to continue rising sharply over the coming months. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

"Sydney's median house price could rise by up to $154,000 by the end of next year if house prices rise in line with Westpac's dwelling price forecast," Canstar data insights director Sally Tindall said.

"For those already in the market, that's welcome news for their equity. For those still saving, the deposit hurdle is likely to get a whole lot steeper, not to mention the difficulty in clearing a bank's serviceability test.

Six-figure price rises would also hit Melbourne and Perth if Westpac's forecasts play out, with the Victorian capital joining Brisbane and Sydney in breaking the $1 million median house price barrier. ﻿

"Melbourne is shaping up as the comeback city in 2026, with double-digit growth on the cards, according to Westpac," Tindall said.

READ MORE: Officer killed in Porepunkah shooting farewelled

Lower interest rates, coupled with low supply and high demand, have helped push prices up. (Joe Armao/The Age)

"This could see Melbourne's median house price go above the million-dollar mark, which for many first home buyers will be a psychological barrier that makes it feel like the goal posts keep moving further away."

The forecasts for price rises have been driven by easing interest rates, as well as the chronic undersupply and high demand that has been plaguing Australia for years.

However, while the Reserve Bank is expecting to hand down at least one more cut this year, and potentially another in early 2026, ANZ today warned that the cash rate may be left where it currently stands following stronger-than-expected GDP figures this week.

"If evidence of consumer spending momentum continues and weakness does not emerge in the CPI or labour market data, the RBA may assess the cash rate as broadly neutral with no further cuts needed," the big four bank's head of Australian economics, Adam Boyton, said.

Tindall said unexpectedly high rates could throw something of a spanner in the housing price works.

"You don't have to look too far back to see how quickly market expectations can change when conditions do," she said.

"The danger is, Australians will borrow to the limit, banking on prices continuing to climb. If circumstances change – whether that's interest rates, job security or the economy – it could leave some households overexposed.

"The more households borrow, the more vulnerable they become to rate rises or shocks to employment."

title: Labor MP calls for WA government to scrap controversial street circuit plans
text:
One of WA's highest-ranking Labor MPs has called on the state government to abandon controversial plans to build an entertainment precinct and street circuit in Burswood.

The $217 million project first proposed in the lead-up to the March state election was pitched as a street circuit for motorsports and cycling which would attract tourists and generate tens of millions of dollars in economic benefits.

But it's been vocally opposed by nearby residents, the Greens and the Liberals, with opposition leader Basil Zempilas constantly using it as an example of what he says are the state government's wrong priorities.

The site of the WA government's proposed Burswood Park multi-use community hub and racetrack. (ABC News: Glyn Jones)

Now, the federal member for Perth and Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Patrick Gorman, has added his voice to the opposition.

"It is no surprise to anyone that as the Member for Perth my longstanding and firm view is that the Burswood Racetrack should not proceed," he said in a statement.

"As a local member I have heard extensive concerns from local constituents and community groups about the significant loss of amenity, environmental impacts and impacts on future housing developments.

Mr Gorman says community concerns have been amplified since the release of the WA government's consultation report. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

" These concerns started immediately after the election commitment was announced and have amplified since the release of the consultation report. "

That report, which suggested there was broad support for the project, was slammed as spin by the Save Burswood Park Alliance which is rallying community voices to oppose the development.

Premier not backing down

A spokesperson for Premier Roger Cook hit back at Mr Gorman's opposition, saying a letter he recently sent contained "a number of factual errors".

"For example, Mr Gorman asserted the precinct was being developed for numerous motorsport events — that's wrong," they said.

Roger Cook has continued to defend the project, which he said would bolster WA's tourism economy. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

'Rita's racetrack' divides opinion Photo shows WA Premier Roger Cook smiles as he sits in a racing car. The WA government's controversial $217 million plan to build a street motorsport circuit at Perth's Burswood Park has incurred the wrath of many — and don't dare call it a motorplex.

"In fact, it will host one Supercars event a year, with the precinct being available for a range of other community events throughout the rest of the year, including cycling, as well as concerts at the new amphitheatre.

"Mr Gorman also incorrectly suggested there would be a loss of urban canopy and green space, when our plan will actually see an increase in the number of trees and natural amenity.

"While we are always interested in the views of our federal representatives, we think it would be most appropriate for Mr Gorman to spend his time in Canberra helping us to secure WA's fair share of infrastructure spending and aged care beds."

Rare rift

Mr Gorman said Mr Cook was leading "one of the best" state Labor governments he had ever seen, and that gave him hope the premier would address community concerns.

"The Cook Labor Government will always have my support and the best way I can support them now is to help build a new fair, transparent, and inclusive consultation process including a new and open site selection process," Mr Gorman said.

Opponents to the plan have been vocal about their concerns. (ABC News: Phoebe Pin)

Such public disagreement over a major policy has been a rarity in the Western Australian Labor Party in recent years which has been defined by its solidarity.

But it does come after Mr Cook and his ministers spent weeks decrying a lack of aged care support from the federal Labor government, especially when it comes to home care packages — an issue which they have blamed for adding pressure to already overflowing hospitals.

title: Pandemic distance did not stop father and son starting wine label
text:
When the COVID pandemic resulted in hard borders between states, winemakers Callum and Michael Garland embarked on a new venture together despite being thousands of kilometres apart.

"It was a way to feel like we were doing something together and side by side, even though we were sort of 3,000km away," Callum said.

"It was a way of keeping in touch and keeping connected. It was our common love I suppose," Michael said.

Callum was in Geelong, Victoria after spending years pursuing his winemaking dream interstate and abroad, while his father was in Western Australia's Great Southern region.

In 2021, the pair launched Fervor Wines and began independently making wines under the same label.

Michael Garland and a young Callum at Garland's winery in Mount Barker. (Supplied)

Some of Callum's first wines, Fervor Nonna Diana and Fervor Nonno Lou, were created in honour of his grandparents.

The father and son now work side by side on Western Australia's southern coast, but the seeds for the venture were sown many years earlier.

Surrounded by winemaking at early age

With fond early memories of growing up at the family winery, Garland's, and birthdays celebrated mid-vintage, winemaking was synonymous with family for Callum.

"I remember Mum taking me up there and being at the cellar door," he said.

"That's one of my first memories, being at our winery in Mount Barker and running around and annoying Dad."

While Callum was immersed in the industry from day dot, it was not until he began working harvest to save for university that his career vision and the world of wine combined.

And his ideas for winemaking were closely intertwined with those of family.

But by this point, Michael had sold the family vineyard and was working at other wineries.

Callum Garland says his earliest memories are of the family winery and vineyard. (Supplied)

"I've been hassling Dad since I got into the wine industry," Callum said.

"Halfway through the first harvest, I was like, 'No, this is what I want, we should do our own thing again, we should do something together.'"

Callum, who was a finalist in the Australian Young Gun of Wine awards last year, returned home in early 2024 to work alongside his father as an assistant winemaker and vineyard manager.

"Bringing back these wines that Dad hadn't tasted before, and we've only talked about over the phone and seeing his joy … that was a pretty special moment," Callum said.

"It's a very, very special place and I probably drank more Great Southern wine in Victoria than I actually did ever, and it fostered a love for this region.

"And the opportunity to work side by side with Dad was huge."

Callum Garland (right) returned to Western Australia to work with his father Michael. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Launching a "tiny" label together, the duo's expectations have been surpassed.

"We were planning on just making, 200 or 300 case batches just from really tiny vineyards," Michael said.

"Then of course, if you're selling out, you start making more.

"We're still not very big, only about 3,500 thousand cases."

A sense of place

Currently selling to the domestic market, Michael said they saw growth opportunities in South-East Asian markets.

"We've just got our first order last week from Singapore, so that's exciting and there's lots of others irons in the fire," Michael said.

"We'll probably be aiming at lots of small markets rather than one big market, having seen what happens in the wine industry when you put a lot of reliance on one market."

Fervor Wines has leased the Gibraltar Rock vineyard in the Porongurups. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

To fill the barrel, they have recently taken on a second vineyard lease at Gibraltar Rock in Porongurup, with a vista of the Stirling Range.

"Half the time you're actually in the clouds," Michael said.

"That delays the ripening so you're picking very, very late in the season … so the grapes actually have more flavour."

The block is a mix of old and new wine riesling, shiraz, chardonnay and pinot.

"If a sense of place means anything, this is a very special site," Callum said.

He is also looking forward to the second vintage with his father since he returned to WA.

"It's always nice, even picking grapes together on early mornings in harvest when we're tired, but we're side by side and working together, that's really the best bits," Callum said.

title: Young apprentices keep butcher trade alive in country town
text:
When it came to deciding on a profession after leaving school, Lilly Reeves did not expect she would be carving out a career as a butcher.

Amid sides of meat hanging at ceiling point and the sound of an electric bandsaw cutting through bone, the 17-year-old throws on her striped apron and sharpens her array of knives ahead of another day, learning the art of butchery.

"I guess I saw Dad doing it and thought it was pretty good," she said.

"Learning all the different cuts, slicing … it's all pretty good."

It is a Friday morning and the butcher shop in downtown Clermont, a small rural and mining town in central Queensland, is abuzz with regulars stocking up for the weekend.

Lilly Reeves is one of two apprentices working at the Clermont shop in central Queensland. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

It is a stark contrast to an industry that, in many places, is a dying trade.

"We've been going just over two years now … it's a good little family operation," Lilly's dad Steve said.

"The butcher shop had closed down out here for nearly 12 months and everyone [in town] missed it, we did.

" We'd drive past and look in and [check] … if we'd see a sign if the shop had re-opened, and in the end, we thought we'd have a crack at it. "

Country butchers vital

From meat trays for the footy club's fundraising raffles to supplying meat to the local pub, butcher shops are the lifeblood of Australia's smaller regional towns.

With over two decades of experience as a butcher, Mr Reeves has seen the slow decline of small town butcher shops.

But his business is going against the grain.

He has doubled his staff, which includes two apprentices, since the re-opening of what he calls the "old-school butcher shop".

It is all hands on deck for the Reeves family, with Lilly, Jasmine and Steve behind the counter. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

Along with Lilly, Steve's eldest daughter, Jasmine, 19, and son, Rhys, 16, work at the shop.

"I think butchering is a dying trade," Mr Reeves said.

" It's hard to find a [qualified] butcher these days. We need to train them up and that's where my kids come in and a few young local lads are keen to do it too. "

With a population of about 3,000, keeping local businesses alive is important for the town, located 4 hours north-west of Rockhampton.

Mr Reeves said there needed to be more support for young apprentices who were facing cost-of-living pressures to keep them in the industry.

"With the mines they've obviously got attractive salaries and stuff like that, but I think in a small business like this, the main thing is keeping a good relationship with the staff," he said.

The local butcher shop is the lifeblood of smaller towns. (ABC News: Bec Whetham)

Rewarding and enjoyable career

The Australian Meat Industry Council said the "local butcher" played a key part in communities, particularly in remote, regional areas.

"Just look at the recent natural disasters such as floods and cyclones, often it's the butcher that is the last shop open in town," the council's chief executive Tim Ryan said.

"Of late, we have also seen an increase in consumer shopping at the local butcher, which has been positive and particularly so."

Tim Ryan is encouraging young people to get into the trade to overcome skilled staff shortages. (Supplied: Australian Meat Industry Council)

Mr Ryan said there were many factors behind the resurgence of consumers choosing the butcher over supermarkets.

"They're far more flexible in [responding to] changing consumer needs and that's probably the real strength of your local butcher shop," he said.

"You really get that tailored service and bits of advice on how to prepare a meal and the products they offer can change from day to day."

The industry says customers are on the increase, with butchers offering a tailored service. (ABC Rural: Daniel Fitzgerald)

Mr Ryan agreed finding and retaining qualified staff and apprentices was difficult.

"Across the board, finding people is really challenging in the industry, particularly getting the right skills," he said.

Women overcoming stereotypes

Apprentice butcher Lilly Reeves is determined to keep her trade alive and cut through stereotypes.

She is part of a mostly female team back in Clermont, and according to Mr Ryan, has joined a growing list of young women getting into the meat industry.

"We're actually seeing a broader trend in terms of numbers of females actually wanting to be in the industry and breaking the stigma that butchery is a male trade," Mr Ryan said.

More women are getting into the meat industry. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

"Over time we can change this image in people's minds and being able to promote young females coming through helps attract more young females in the future."

As she handles another slab of meat to slice up, Ms Reeves is bucking a trend in more ways than one.

Halfway through her apprenticeship, the country teen said she was planning for a future in her chosen trade.

"We're thinking of opening up slaughter yards [down the track], so I might give that a crack and see how that goes."

title: WA's agricultural history celebrated at $20m vintage tractor gathering
text:
In a muddy field in country Western Australia, a slice of history rolled into town.

The farming town of Kojonup is usually bathed in a sea of yellow in September as the canola crops come into bloom.

But on the outskirts of the grain and sheep farming community, 300 kilometres south of Perth, one field was coloured yellow for a different reason.

Some of the tractors at the show were 100 years old. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

More than 100 new and vintage tractors were trucked in from across the state to celebrate 100 years since the first Caterpillar was used in WA at the Sunnydale Vintage Day on Saturday.

"There's a lot of history to some of these machines," Kojonup farmer Peter Spurr said.

"There are a couple of machines here, they've got a lot of very good stories behind them."

Mr Spurr estimated the total value of the collection at $20 million.

Peter Spurr with his 100-year-old Holt Caterpillar. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

More than machines

The farmer and prolific tractor collector, who laid claim to owning the oldest tractor in the show, a 100-year-old Holt Caterpillar, said the vintage machinery was an important part of the country's history.

"They opened the country up from the early 1920s all the way right through to the 60s, clearing farms," he said.

" It just opened up agriculture in WA and across Australia in general. "

"It's very special to have this machinery around, still active; it's just a testament to the brand… to see the oldest to the latest here today, and it's all still in fairly good working order."

About 1,000 people attended the event. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

Mr Spurr has more than 100 "bits of gear" in his personal collection.

"One day it will be too many, but at the moment I'm still collecting," he said.

Far from gathering dust, the farmer said each machine had a role to play.

"They still get out to do a special job every now and again, so they're not quite completely tucked away in the shed," he said.

"They're still pretty active on the farm."

An iconic hue

In 1931, the brand changed the colour scheme of its tractors to hi-way yellow to increase visibility and safety, but the oldest and most historic still retain the original battleship grey paint job.

The vintage tractors were displayed at a farm in Kojonup. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

One of those early grey tractors, a Caterpillar Sixty that helped shape WA, belongs to Bob Lukins.

"The old Caterpillar Sixty, from 1928, was used mainly in the early days to clear the Albany Highway," he said.

"They used it to pull the trees down.

"It's got MRD stamped on the chassis of the tractor — that was the main road board in those days."

Bob Lukins's Caterpillar Sixty was used to clear the Albany Highway. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

A founding member of the WA Vintage Tractor and Machinery Association, and a vintage tractor collector, Mr Lukins said he had no idea of the Sixty's history when he purchased the machine, which now holds a special place in his collection.

"I got quite excited about that because Albany Highway is a major road, and this tractor was part of that history," he said.

"It's the only one in Western Australia, so it's quite a rare old tractor."

This vintage Caterpillar Diesel Forty was part of the display. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

More than 1,000 people attended the event, which Mr Lukins said took months of planning to consolidate the more than 100 tractors, graders, and bobcats into one location.

A feat that would likely go unmatched for some time.

"We'll never ever see a collection of Caterpillars ever again like this, I don't think so," he said.

title: How the WA government's health carve-up is performing
text:
It's almost six months since a large WA Labor Government remained, well, large and still in charge.

On March 8, Premier Roger Cook finally stepped out from the shadow of predecessor Mark McGowan, romping to victory in the state election.

The former health minister made his first order of business a bold re-shaping of his old beat, arguably the most challenging portfolio confronting a government.

It raised eyebrows at the time.

First-time minister Meredith Hammat was handed the health and mental health portfolios, backed by an additional four ministers — responsible for health infrastructure, aged care and seniors, medical research and the brand new preventative health ministry.

Meredith Hammat has had a challenging start to life as WA health minister. (ABC News: Keane Bourke )

The government said it was the right choice to bring a "team approach" to a big portfolio, and experts largely agreed.

So, has it worked having five ministers working under the same umbrella? It depends on who you ask.

Division of Labor

If the past two months have demonstrated anything, it's that Ms Hammat has a tough job — even with a lightened workload.

A worse-than-expected flu season combined with our ageing population forced the Department of Health's hand to reschedule over 100 elective surgeries in August following "unprecedented" emergency department demand.

The state then recorded back-to-back record ambulance ramping figures.

WA sets new ambulance ramping record Western Australia again breaks the state record for the amount of time ambulances spent ramped outside hospitals, despite more than 100 elective surgeries being postponed to ease pressure.

Amid this came a barrage of questions over the state of Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital in Nedlands.

It resulted in the government coughing up $50 million for maintenance at WA's ageing hospitals.

Having a seasoned minister like John Carey, already used to dealing with his tricky housing portfolio, copping the flak for infrastructure issues would have eased the load on Ms Hammat.

But the WA opposition hasn't seen the distribution of the vast portfolio as a sign of leadership.

"By spreading it around, what they've also done is spread the blame," opposition leader Basil Zempilas said.

WA opposition leader Basil Zempilas says the government needs to do more to ease the health crisis. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"We've seen a conga line of finger pointing in different directions.

"When there's been a specific issue, often the minister's [Ms Hammat's] first reaction is to say 'Oh no, that's not me, that's one of the other health ministers — you'll have to go and speak to them' … that's not good enough.

'Laser-like focus'

It's something the Australian Medical Association (AMA) is also concerned about.

"We're very very cautiously optimistic, but if we start to see that there's deliberate handballing to prevent taking responsibility for key issues, then I'd be having a very different conversation," AMA WA President Dr Kyle Hoath said.

The government thinks the health ministry is operating well as a team.

Dr Kyle Hoath is the AMA WA president. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"It's tough, we know it's tough, but my government is up for the challenge," a confident Roger Cook told reporters in Exmouth on Friday.

Likewise, a government spokesperson said a team of ministers with a "laser-like focus on different aspects" of health was "the best way" to address complex challenges.

"Together, under the leadership of Health Minister Meredith Hammat, we're strengthening our health system by investing in hospitals and increasing our health workforce, and we are spearheading reforms to tackle ambulance ramping," the spokesperson said.

'Trapped' in winter cycle

Terry Slevin, an adjunct professor and chief executive officer of the Public Health Association of Australia, thinks the division of health is a good idea.

WA patient devastated as complex surgery cancelled day before Photo shows A woman sits in her home, being interviewed A patient caught up in the immense pressure being placed on WA hospitals says her planned surgery being cancelled has put her under significant stress and eroded her trust in the health system.

"Roger Cook knows the extraordinary complexity of the health portfolio, he's had to wrestle with it," Mr Slevin said.

"So having broken it up into more chewable chunks means all of those people can focus on each of those big challenges — mental health, infrastructure, prevention, research — and they can give it greater attention and engage with the people who have the best ideas."

Mr Slevin says it's still "relatively early days" and the ministry needs more time to become a well-oiled machine, and called for a review after 18 months to two years.

He's naturally the most interested in Sabine Winton's portfolio — preventative health — and thinks she could be doing more to foster healthier communities to prevent ED presentations.

"If we're going to deal with the ambulance ramping, the queues for clinical services in the future, the time to start is now with regard to dialling that demand down," he said.

Terry Slevin says the integrated approach may take time to bear fruit. (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

Dr Hoath echoed the sentiment.

"We get very trapped in this cycle of ramping, of winter, of vaccine, the crisises we hit, rather than taking a step back and trying to prevent the problem from getting bigger," Dr Hoath said.

The government insists Ms Winton is focused on this through things like vaccinations, but peak groups want more tangible results to point to.

Time needed

From a patient perspective, stronger connection between state and federal health ministers is also urgent.

"The state government has a number of levers and they are important, but I think that what we need to see is our governance mechanisms joining up to actually understand the community's perspective on the ground," Health Consumers Council Executive Director Clare Mullen said.

August saw WA set another unwanted record for ambulance ramping. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

Ms Mullen says this looks like consumers more "actively involved" in the early stages of decision making in hospital infrastructure projects, for example.

If a grace period is given to the government, its still got time to iron out the kinks.

But with an opposition quick to seize on any missteps, it might want to nip issues in the bud sooner rather than later.

Loading...

title: Fyfe bows out after Freo loss, saying 'I don't think I needed anything else'
text:
Fremantle great Nat Fyfe says he was left feeling numb after his AFL career was brought to a close in a heartbreaking one-point loss to Gold Coast.

Fyfe said he still ended his AFL career content despite not winning the premiership he so desperately craved, and he was optimistic the current group had "five or six" more bites at the cherry.

Fyfe's career came to a close on Saturday night when Fremantle suffered a heartbreaking one-point loss to Gold Coast in a pulsating elimination final at Perth Stadium.

The Dockers led by six points with less than two minutes remaining, but a Mac Andrew goal with 72 seconds to go followed by a David Swallow behind with just nine seconds left on the clock sealed the 11.14 (80) to 12.7 (79) win for Gold Coast.

Swallow, like Fyfe, had announced he would retire at the end of the season, and would have been the one hanging up his boots if the Suns had lost.

After being interviewed on the field, he went to Fyfe and the two veterans spoke at the end of a big night.

Fyfe was then given a guard of honour, with skipper Alex Pearce and Luke Ryan chairing him off.

In an honest and emotional interview after the match, Fyfe revealed he had been in some doubt for the match after rolling his ankle at training on Tuesday.

"When you're at my age and with the scar tissue, a small ankle injury can turn into a pretty major thing, but it wasn't too bad," Fyfe said.

The 33-year-old won two Brownlow Medals, three club best and fairest awards and three All-Australians during his decorated 248-game career, as well as captaining Fremantle.

But team success eluded him, with the 15-point loss to Hawthorn in the 2013 grand final the closest Fyfe got to a flag.

Fyfe was philosophical after his dream ended on Saturday night.

"I don't think I needed anything else from the game," Fyfe said.

"We all want to win premierships. I do have some contentedness that I tried everything and gave absolutely everything I could to the club and evolved myself along the way.

"In some ways, maybe my journey it was more important for me not to win than to win.

"I just think that's fitting — the game does not give up its rewards very easily and there's a lot more times you finish a season heartbroken than the opposite.

"To be able to get back and actually be involved in this game this year … I'm really grateful I got to play in another final again."

Fremantle have featured in finals just twice since 2015 — in 2022 and 2025.

But with the bulk of the talent-laden squad still in their early-to-mid 20s, Fyfe sees a bright future.

"We've only lost three games of the last 14, we've learned to win on the road, we've given ourselves every chance of evolving the way you'd like a list to," Fyfe said.

"I think we genuinely have got the calibre of players in the right profile to have five or six bites at winning a premiership."

David Swallow kept his career going with the match-winning score, but the Suns veteran went to Freo's Nat Fyfe to congratulate him on his career. (Getty Images: AFL Photos: Michael Willson)

Fyfe has been plagued by injuries in the latter part of his glittering career.

This year alone he dealt with knee, hamstring and calf issues, admitting that he thought he may not be able to come back on numerous occasions.

"The game tried many different times to tell me the end of the road was near and so I walk away knowing this was definitely the right time," Fyfe said.

"I think I came to a point last year where I felt like I'd turned every stone, given absolutely everything I could.

"Where the story went from there was out of my hands. Hopefully I get some closure and peace of mind that this part of my journey with Fremantle — I did everything I could.

"I finish disappointed in some ways because of the way this season went. But those memories will eventually turn into fond ones for what's been an amazing experience."

So, what's next for Fyfe, a man who has endured 25 surgeries across his career?

"A period of rest," Fyfe said.

AAP/ABC

title: Gold Coast rail 30 years in the making cut short of final destination
text:
A long time ago, Sydney virtually stopped building public transport infrastructure.

When it resumed, retrofitting the city was painful and expensive, according to Bond University urban planning researcher Daniel O'Hare.

"It's been so much more expensive because they waited," Dr O'Hare said.

"And very much more disruptive because the city had to grow up without it and they had to retrofit it."

The south entrance of Gadigal station on Sydney's new Metro line was not cheap. (Supplied)

On the Gold Coast, the rapidly growing city realised it too was headed for gridlock, long before construction began on Sydney's massive underground metro or light rail projects.

"It was identified we would have gridlock unless we developed some kind of rapid transit system," Dr O'Hare said.

30-year plan

Light rail was chosen shortly after a 1998 transport plan, using population growth and migration patterns, identified problems.

The Gold Coast's population continues to surge. (Facebook: City of Gold Coast)

The city's population has since doubled and is expected to surge towards a million people by 2040.

This week the final, fourth stage that would see a light rail line run the full length of the Gold Coast's coastal strip was scrapped by Deputy Premier Jarrod Bleijie.

A review found the 13-kilometre line to the airport would cost between $5.7 billion and $9.85 billion.

Mr Blejiie also cited a survey detailing the feelings of nearby residents about the project.

Now, similar to another south-east Queensland rail project, the Gold Coast line is expected to terminate at Burleigh Heads with buses servicing the route south to the city's international airport.

Changing character

Burleigh Pavilion owner Ben May said he was not surprised by the decision, because it had been foreshadowed for months.

But that does not mean he thinks it is ideal.

"The reality is we're left with a half-finished transport solution," Mr May said.

"The fact that it was started without a guarantee that it would be finished is absolutely laughable."

Ben May has businesses in Queensland and NSW. (ABC Gold Coast: Tara Cassidy)

He said swapping between trams and buses was a turn-off for commuters, and an interchange could transform Burleigh Heads.

"No-one wants to live at the end of the line," he said.

"As someone from Sydney who knows what that looks like — it's a really poor result.

" Part of the jewel of Burleigh was that it wasn't Surfers Paradise. "

'Views remain mixed'

Cavill Avenue in Surfers Paradise isn't popular with some Gold Coast residents. (ABC News: Tom Forbes)

For some who live on the Gold Coast, Surfers Paradise is a dirty word.

There are fears of a concrete canyon stretching south, spurred along by the light rail, as one of many reasons some residents are opposed to the project.

Luxury beachfront apartments rise above Palm Beach which had been largely single storey.

Some say the developments follow a decades-long trend.

"We're seeing development all through the southern Gold Coast. It's market driven," said Coolangatta-based councillor Gail O'Neill.

A post card image of Palm Beach and Currumbin circa 1960. (Supplied: John Engelander & Co via the Centre for the Government of Queensland)

Some residents felt they do not have a choice about development, or how transport would work in the area.

A recent government survey report found 60 per cent of those felt like they had not been listened to and were told light rail was "a foregone conclusion".

The report also found "views on preferred transport modes remain mixed", while transport demand in the already congested area is expected to increase by 32 per cent by 2041.

The report said the extension of rail was "not an alternative to improving other public transport on the southern Gold Coast".

Tit-for-tat

These issues featured heavily in recent local, state and federal elections, which Mr May said had impacted local politics in the area.

"[Burleigh MP] Hermann Vorster's been pretty vocal on it and I guess he's been elected, he feels, on the back of doing this review and then probably coming to this conclusion," Mr May said.

Steven Miles and Meghan Scanlon with a sign of Hermann Vorster in Burleigh. (ABC News: Nicholas McElroy)

While it was ultimately a Crisafulli government decision, Queensland opposition leader Steven Miles said the area would become a bus depot and he took aim at Mr Vorster's involvement.

"Overwhelmingly, across the Gold Coast, this is a very popular project," Mr Miles said.

"But instead of listening to people, that overwhelming opinion, [the government has] listened to a few. A noisy minority."

Mr Vorster said designs for the area were now being worked on by the transport department.

He said only the opposition was talking about the area becoming a bus depot.

Laura Gerber, Jarrod Bleijie and Hermann Vorster announced that Stage Four of the light rail would not be going ahead. (ABC News: Mackenzie Colahan)

He said buses servicing the line would layover at a shopping centre several kilometres away before picking up passengers.

"Had light rail Stage Four progressed we still would have had five to seven years of buses connecting to light rail," Mr Vorster said.

The late change to the project creates a conundrum for the area, said Griffith University transport expert Matthew Burke.

Light Rail Stage Three is currently under construction. The last stretch, Stage Four, could be serviced by buses. (ABC News)

He said planners now needed to create a "seamless" transfer between buses and trams.

"There are ways to do that, including double-deckering [stations], which will cut off the views at that location," Professor Burke said.

"There are other ways to do it, by taking out road space, footpath space, everything else. There's going to be challenges there."

Urban planning researcher Daniel O'Hare. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

Whether or not debate is helpful, Dr O'Hare said the latest decision could lead to two agitated communities.

He said politicians and planners could have been less antagonistic and more open as opposition to light rail emerged over the years.

"I really don't think the Burleigh Heads community will tolerate having a deterioration as a result [of cutting the route short]," Dr O'Hare said.

"So, they will get active too. You'll have two very active communities … Burleigh Heads and Palm Beach."

Over time, over budget

The "iron law" of mega projects states that they are often over budget and over schedule.

But the latest price tag led Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate to ask "are the tracks gold-plated?"

The light rail span across Currumbin Creek was expected to be expensive. (Supplied: Queensland government)

While budgets blow out on transport projects in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne, Dr O'Hare said similarly priced Gold Coast projects seemed to be less controversial.

He pointed to the 16km Coomera Connector, a road which has doubled in price.

"Nobody questions $3 billion on the current stage," he said.

He said the next stage of the road would likely exceed the costs of Stage Four of the light rail.

"No one seems to question that," he said.

Whole city approach

While the Gold Coast developed as a string of interconnected areas, rather than a central hub, Dr O'Hare said thinking of the city and south-east Queensland as a whole could be more helpful.

"I'd like us to put the whole city into context so we can get the various villages … talking, not only among themselves but also to each other," he said.

60 years effectively rebuilding a ripped up rail line Photo shows The old South Coast rail line can be seen from above, running through Coolangatta. Melbourne's failure to build a train line to its international airport could be a little humiliating, but Queensland has been rebuilding a line it ripped up in the 1960s.

The government is now working on designs to service the southern Gold Coast with buses, but Dr O'Hare said he hoped the scrapping of the rail project was not permanent.

"I'm hopeful that the current situation is a postponement and a catching of breath [rather] than 'it's all over'," he said.

He said neglecting public transport altogether would be too expensive.

"You lock us into the car-based future forever, which is one where there are never enough lanes, never enough parking spaces," he said.

"And when you get to where you're going it's dominated by parking rather than places."

title: After waiting 50 years, remote community resorts to Chinese prefab homes
text:
There are some nights Raylene Robinson would rather sleep under the open sky than in her government-sanctioned home.

Mould creeps up the walls, floorboards warp at odd angles, and the tap won't stop running.

"It's making me feel like I [should] go out bush and live for a while," the Martu elder says.

" Houses are falling apart … it is scary. "

Raylene Robinson says people need to be able to come back home to Punmu. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Deep in the Western Desert, on the banks of an ephemeral salt lake, a remote housing crisis is leaving families to languish in overcrowded, crumbling, and improvised humpies.

Bureaucratic deadlock and shifting government responsibility has seen 50 years pass without a new build.

The community of Punmu, more than 1,300 kilometres north-east of Perth, is sick of waiting.

It has gathered together enough money to buy a pair of Chinese-made, prefabricated homes so it can triage its most vulnerable residents.

The irony of turning overseas to build a future on her ancestral country is not lost on Ms Robinson.

"Desert is our home; Punmu is our home," she says.

" The government needs to come and see how we're living out here. "

A solution that 'won't last'

Two prefabricated houses made in China from shipping containers will travel the bumpy, dirt road to Punmu later this year.

The move seeks to circumvent long-standing land tenure disputes, which the WA government has blamed for blocking the construction of additional houses.

In the meantime, community coordinator Edith Costello, a 59-year-old former tradie from Queensland, spends her waking hours making "endless" emergency repairs to keep things afloat.

"Fixing blockages, rebuilding septics, patching holes in walls to stop snakes coming in: it's a band-aid fix," Ms Costello says.

Edith Costello traverses Punmu by utility buggy, making house repair calls. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Advocates like Ms Costello say the aging housing stock in the Western Desert is jeopardising Martu traditional owners and their millennia-deep connection to country.

The homes in Punmu date back half a century. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

With about 180 permanent residents, more than a third of Punmu's 21 homes have been condemned as "irreparable" and fit for demolition.

Financed by the local shop, tourist accommodation, and fuel stop, the new container houses cost the community $20,000 to buy and a further $40,000 to ship and install.

It is dipping into a kitty, Ms Costello says, they can hardly afford.

"We don't have the funds to purchase government-standard housing, so we've purchased two expandable container homes, which I know won't last," she says.

"But if they last 10 years, then they've paid for themselves."

Inside a remote housing crisis

One of Australia's last peoples to encounter colonial society, the Martu of the Western Desert are today among its most disadvantaged.

Rocketing rates of renal disease mean their average life expectancy does not surpass 45 years.

Inside Ms Robinson's Punmu home, where she lives at close quarters with three generations of her family, the bathroom walls are rotting and the electric lights overhead fail to switch on.

Water pours perpetually from the faucet; its inner valve has long since rusted through.

Plumbing issues, electrical failure, and insect infestations are typical in Punmu. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

"These houses are old," Ms Costello says in the darkness.

"They weren't purpose-built, and it's not damage from not being looked after; they're just old.

" Every night, I go to sleep knowing people in my community are living in horrid conditions. "

The WA state government constructed the housing in Punmu during the 1980s as the Martu sought to return to the desert after they were forcibly removed in the early 20th century.

Punmu was created in 1981 as the Martu returned to the desert. (ABC News: Charlie McLean)

The buildings themselves were gifted to the community to self-manage, but because they fall within the boundaries of Karlamilyi National Park, residents do not hold tenure over the land.

WA government officials say the discrepancy legally prevents them from building any more houses.

Then-environment minister Stephen Dawson signed a statement of intent in 2021 to excise Punmu and another Martu community, Parnngurr, from the national park, but no further action has been taken.

All the while, brutal wind, sun, and cyclones have exacted a heavy toll on the housing.

"I think we have been left behind," Ms Robinson says.

"The government didn't want to do anything for us."

People pushed into town

The deterioration of properties in Punmu, alongside the region's other Martu communities of Jigalong, Parnngurr and Kunawarritji, is threatening to engulf the closest regional centre as well.

With nowhere on Martu country to turn, a growing number of people have been forced into the mining town of Newman, 700km south-west of Punmu.

This diaspora is fuelling overcrowding in the iron-ore hub, from which about 78 million tonnes of Australia's most lucrative commodity is extracted by mining giant BHP annually.

Much of the raw material will be exported to China for refinement into steel and eventually turned into products like shipping containers or prefabricated homes.

Last year, BHP generated nearly $24 billion in profits.

Newman is home to the world's largest open-pit iron-ore mine, operated by majority owner BHP. (ABC News: Charlie Mclean)

Roughly, 200 Martu live in the suburb of East Newman, a neighbourhood likened by locals to the war-ravaged areas of "East Timor" amid the 1970s Indonesian occupation.

The boarded-up windows and graffiti-strewn streets are in stark contrast to the outfitted 4WDs and new homes of senior mine managers on the opposite end of town.

BHP owns 113 of these derelict houses, with a large proportion sitting in East Newman.

East Newman has earned the moniker "East Timor" from locals for its dilapidated condition. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

The miner hopes to make 13 of the properties habitable by the end of the year.

It is part of a broader commitment to revitalise the company town, where Indigenous health outcomes and incarceration levels rank as some of the worst in the nation.

BHP contributed almost $11 million to community programs during the past financial year, largely through the Newman Futures initiative it first launched in 2020.

The enterprise's landmark East Newman Precinct Structure Plan was co-designed with Martu native title bodies to overhaul the dilapidated strip, including designs for new housing, laundry facilities, and a convenience store.

While a spokesperson noted "positive momentum" on several of the projects, they could not point to a single building yet delivered under the plan, which only secured state government approval in 2024.

Some services, such as free meal deliveries and youth activities, are already underway.

But Martu elder and Punmu resident Milton Chapman says the significant resources being mobilised in Newman neglect the root of the issue: a lack of housing in remote communities.

"That didn't solve the problem," he says.

" We need houses. "

For years, Martu organisations have pitched the bolstering of their communities as a money-saving exercise.

In 2018, the Pilbara Development Commission hired Social Ventures Australia Consulting to produce a cost-benefit analysis of investment in the Western Desert.

Its 2024 final report, which drew on ABS census and WA Police Force data, found the imprisonment of Martu adults and youth cost the WA government $13 million in 2023.

"The rate of offending in [the Western Desert communities] … is identical to that of the general population," the report read.

" The rate of Martu offending in Newman is 95 times higher … than the general population. "

Punmu , like other remote Martu communities, has banned all alcohol. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Mr Chapman insists the explanation is simple.

Newman is not traditional Martu country; alcohol is readily available, and the threat of incarceration looms.

Conversely, he says living in a remote community allows elders to shield young people from bad influences and a revolving justice system.

"That's where our culture is … it is safe for our kids," Mr Chapman says.

"Kids breaking in and stealing cars, that [does] happen in the community, but we want our kids to be out here."

Politics compounding problem

Disagreements between state and federal governments over the maintenance of remote communities have only added to the uncertainty.

The rift flared in 2015 when former prime minister Tony Abbott labelled living in remote communities a "lifestyle choice" taxpayers should not subsidise.

That same year, the federal government stopped providing housing, power, and water services to remote communities and passed responsibility to the states.

The WA government has pledged to repair 22 homes. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Through its Remote Communities Fund, the WA government has set aside close to $20 million to improve 22 homes across three Martu communities: Punmu, Parnngurr, and Kunawarritji.

According to the Department of Housing and Works, 62 total houses make up these settlements, although one community might accommodate upwards of 800 people for cultural events.

It also intends to build new homes in Jigalong, of rabbit-proof fence fame, where it has entered a housing management agreement.

Likewise, the federal government has pledged $50 million to repair homes in remote Indigenous communities across the country between 2025 and 2030.

Edith Costello says the community has been waiting a long time for investment in housing. (ABC News: Charlie Mclean)

Ms Costello says extreme construction costs render the current amount of investment a drop in the ocean for the Western Desert.

That is why Punmu is carving its own path forward.

"The community's been waiting a very, very long time for any action to be made to renew the housing," she explains.

" We're dealing with people whose life expectancy is 39 … and housing is just a basic right. "

title: Wallaroos through to Women's Rugby World Cup QF despite England loss
text:
A 47-7 defeat to England has failed to dampen the spirits of Australia's rugby women, who are marching to the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals.

The Wallaroos had to avoid a 76-point defeat by the rampant tournament favourites to book their place in the last eight and their excellent, ferocious first-half display in Brighton on Saturday (Sunday AEST) effectively ensured that grim prospect was never really on the cards.

Instead, in front of a 30,000-strong crowd including the Princess of Wales, the Australians were left celebrating the chance to cause an upset in next Saturday's (Sunday AEST) quarterfinal against Canada, the world's number two side who had earlier beaten Scotland 40-19 in Exeter to maintain their unbeaten record.

"We are really happy with the performance — especially in that first half, we really gave it to them — and we're just going to stick with those positives," said skipper Siokapesi Palu, who led her Australians excellently.

The Wallaroos went into the final game of the pool knowing exactly what they had to do.

The United States needed to beat Samoa by as many points as possible to have a chance of advancing, and they beat the Pacific nation 60-0 in York.

Led by a four-try performance from Freda Tafuna, the Americans led by 27-0 at half-time, and went on to score 10 tries without reply.

However, Australia's big points differential lead meant the Wallaroos would have had to lose by 76 points against England, without scoring a bonus point, to miss out.

Despite coach John Mitchell, the former All Blacks' mentor, declaring that England aimed to be ruthless hunters, the hosts were taken aback by how the Wallaroos came at them early on with hooker Adiana Talakai ploughing over for the sixth-minute try from a driving maul that really eased their job.

The Aussies needed to score four tries, or lose by less than seven points, to earn the bonus point that would have guaranteed their progression and for the first half-an-hour, that didn't even seem wholly out of the question as they still led the world's number one side, who now haven't lost a Test in a record-equalling 30 matches.

That superb opening, featuring real resilience in defence and enterprise in attack, proved absolutely critical in their bid to ensure their points difference ended up 35 points better than the Americans, even though there felt an inevitability that England, after a scrappy opening, would eventually start wearing them down.

England finally hit the front with three tries before the break from Jess Breach — on her 50th appearance — Abbie Ward and Sadia Kabeya, and as Australia began to tire amid the wave of attacks from the hosts after halftime, further scores followed from Kabeya, a double from Kelsey Clifford and Sarah Bern.

Yet despite conceding seven tries in total at the Brighton & Hove Albion Stadium, the side coached by former England player Jo Yapp never really looked like conceding the avalanche of points that would have consigned them to an early exit.

Yapp, who's leaving as coach after the tournament, said: "I don't know if the scoreline was a fair reflection, but in the second half we lost momentum, we lost a couple of key set-pieces and then we were on the back foot. Credit to England, they capitalised on that.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"But the positive thing is we created opportunities, got field position, just we couldn't execute. I'm proud of the first half, the way we took it to them."

The Australians finished second in pool A, and will now face Canada in the quarterfinals.

The Scots came second in pool B and will now face England in the last eight.

It's going to be a tall order against Canada, who beat the Wallaroos 45-7 in their Pacific Four Series clash in Brisbane in May.

"We know what to expect, we'll preview them this week and we'll focus on ourselves," Yapp said.

AAP/ABC

title: Young dad takes over sheep station 'bigger than Singapore' to keep legacy
text:
Fourth-generation farmer Sam Beven is already forging the path for the next generation — his lively young brood of kids who are growing up on the property where he ran amok as a boy.

Last year, his father, Randal Beven, handed over the reins to Sturt's Meadows Station, a 186,000-acre property — "a little bit bigger than Singapore" — about 70 kilometres north of Broken Hill.

In an age when fewer farms are being passed down through the family, the Bevens' succession plan could be a model for other farming families.

Sam and Erin Beven with their sons Duncan, Harvey and Walter. (Supplied: Beven family)

Although his parents still live on the station, which mostly runs sheep, including dorpers and merinos, with some cattle, at 33 years of age, Sam is in charge.

Sam's mum, nurse Jo Beven, said the whole family was "very proud of him".

" The family farm thing is becoming a bit less common these days, so let's hope we can hang on to it for this generation and he can protect it for the next. "

Cementing his place as a strong member of the farming community, Sam was elected president of the Pastoralists' Association of West Darling this year, making him one of the youngest people to serve in the role in the organisation's 118-year history.

Growing up on the family farm

The father-of-three, who will soon welcome his fourth child with his wife Erin, said he knew from a young age he would eventually take over Sturt's Meadows Station, despite being the middle child of three boys.

This resolve was further strengthened during his school years, when Sam and his brothers lived with their mother in Broken Hill, where they attended school, before returning to the station and their father on weekends and holidays.

Brothers Jack, Stuart and Sam Beven as boys growing up at Sturt's Meadows Station. (Supplied: Beven family)

"Dad did his best to get into town as much as he could one or two nights a week [to see us]," Sam said.

" [Dad] was always doing a lot of work on the station, but there was always time for us on the weekends … teaching with motorbikes and sheep work and various sorts of things. "

Randal said most of his memories of Sam involved his middle son falling off things and hurting himself.

Sam Beven suffered life-threatening injuries when he crashed his motorbike into this gate in 2017. (ABC Broken Hill: Katherine Spackman)

However, his most serious injury occurred in 2017 when he was an adult.

Then in his mid-20s, Sam crashed his motorbike through a metal gate on the family station.

He credits his survival to the quick thinking of his paramedic brother, Stuart, and an emergency doctor who insisted he be transported to Adelaide for treatment.

Handing over the reins

Sam officially took over management of Sturt's Meadows about 12 months ago, when his father retired at 60.

Randal and Jo Beven on Sturt's Meadows Station, 70km north of Broken Hill, in far west NSW. (ABC Broken Hill: Katherine Spackman)

But, Randal said, the transition had been underway for several years following the selling of dorper sheep to Sam.

At the time, it had been obvious to the older grazier that his son had new ideas about how to make things more profitable for the station.

"I had sold all of the dorpers to Sam so that he had a means of making an income and a toehold into the property itself, which left me only with merinos," Randal said.

Sturt's Meadows Station runs both dorper and merino sheep. (ABC Broken Hill: Katherine Spackman)

Overpriced sheep stations

Randal says the price of sheep stations is wildly overpriced at about $70 to $75 per acre, which affects the profitability for the next generation.

"If you borrow money on that, you can't make enough to pay the interest. So it makes it very hard for the next generations to get started," he said.

Sturt's Meadows Station is the size of Singapore. (ABC Broken Hill: Katherine Spackman)

When Randal took over from his own father, Peter, he paid him a certain amount of money and then an ongoing lease figure.

"When it came time to do it with Sam, we did it slightly differently. He paid me a certain amount of money, which was more, but then with no lease," he said.

"So I've got enough money to live on, but he doesn't have to pay me lease payments anymore.

" But he did have to take over the ongoing lease payments to my parents because it's a generational thing. "

Randal said he wanted to hand over the running of the station to Sam so the young father had the means to employ a governess.

Six-year-old Harvey Beven with governess Matilda Raphael, who moved to the station at the start of the year. (Supplied)

"We hired our first governess this year and she's been a godsend," Sam said.

"We built a house for a governess to live in [and] we built a school room, so our oldest, Harvey, and ... second-born Duncan ... can spend the whole day there."

Advocating for family farms

Former president of the Pastoralists' Association of West Darling Terry Smith said it was important for the next generation of graziers and farmers to be business savvy.

He said Sam, who has replaced him at the helm of the association, was "doing a really good job".

"He's certainly got a grip on the issues," Terry said.

"It's a reasonable responsibility and a lot of people in the industry come to the Pastoralists' Association of West Darling with their issues, and that feeds back to someone like Sam and the council to come up with a solution for it."

The agri-political lobby organisation represents about 100 members in the far west of NSW.

Terry Smith says Sam Beven is doing a great job in the president's role. (ABC Broken Hill: Bill Ormonde)

title: The RBA has never known what to do about property prices, former deputy governor says
text:
Have you wondered how the Reserve Bank of Australia came up with its "2-3 per cent" target for inflation?

Do you like what's happened to property prices in the inflation-targeting era?

Last week, the RBA published a fascinating and candid interview with Stephen Grenville.

Australian economy grows 1.8pc Photo shows Welder works at InQuik Engineering in Newcastle. The Australian economy has grown slightly faster than economists were expecting thanks to a dramatic increase in household spending.

Dr Grenville worked at the RBA between 1982 and 2001 (his last five years as deputy governor).

He was at the RBA when it adopted its inflation target in the early 1990s and asserted its right to move interest rates up and down without political interference.

In his interview, Dr Grenville talked about the RBA's ongoing struggle to know what to do about asset prices, including property prices.

He said Australia's inflation-targeting framework still had unresolved issues.

But does he think inflation targeting has worked well?

"We had two decades where it worked well and one decade where, in my view, it didn't work so well," he said. "It worked well until 2010 […] "[But] it shouldn't get too much of the blame for its less good performance in the third decade, and there's still a lot to be said for it. "[It] still looks to me to be the best we can do."

When did the interview occur?
